Your neighbor,

(5/6) I love these memories, but my job now in Congress is to make sure other families can keep making happy memories. It means working to end the gun violence that took my Jordan, keeping kids healthy, getting our economy back-on-track, and finally ending this pandemic, too.

(4/6) Sitting in my car, I shut my eyes and heard Jordan hollering and splashing one moment. A second later, I‚Äôm hearing the music we played at his funeral.

That‚Äôs how grief is: it‚Äôs not a linear process. The tiniest thing happens, and it all comes rushing back.

(3/6) Those lines were always so long, sometimes 45 minutes or more.

I‚Äôd tell Jordan that I love him. That I‚Äôm proud of him. Then, I‚Äôd hold him tight all the way down.

(2/6) Jordan always wanted to ride the tallest ones, even before he was tall enough to go on his own!

Climbing to the top, I‚Äôd remind him: ‚ÄúHold onto your shorts,‚Äù as he insisted on wearing trunks that were too big for him, and I‚Äôd hold him‚Äîlaughing‚Äîall the way down the slide.

To recap,¬†#WHPA¬†would:

1)¬†Protect¬†the right to abortion on the federal level¬†for both¬†patients¬†and providers
2)¬†Establish¬†a strong enforcement mechanism to challenge existing and future anti-abortion laws
#WHPA¬†also¬†gives the Department of Justice‚Äîas well as abortion providers and their patients‚Äîthe ability¬†to block¬†state laws that single out and restrict action to abortion care.

That's where #WHPA comes in.¬†At its core, #WHPA establishes a federal¬†right for¬†patients to receive abortion care without restrictive barriers, and for health care professionals to provide it.¬†That means no abortion bans and no medically unnecessary restrictions.

For many people, these restrictions have meant the right to abortion is only a right on paper, not in practice. This is particularly true for communities of color & people with low incomes. We need a strong federal response to stop these attacks on the state level.

In 2021 alone,¬†states have enacted 105 abortion restrictions.

That¬†includes¬†outrageous laws meant to¬†intimidate those seeking an abortion, like requiring providers to read medically inaccurate scripts or forcing patients to undergo unnecessary & invasive treatments.

We spread the myth that paid leave is some kind of paid vacation, instead of the fight for one‚Äôs life that it often is.
We continue the embarrassment of being the only wealthy nation in the world without any paid leave, even as our European counterparts provide on average 22 weeks.

Yet we continue to ask families ‚Äì namely women ‚Äì to fend for themselves and choose between their health or family and a paycheck. We stand by as families face financial ruin or quit their jobs in order to honor their responsibilities.

And as women, we feel this tremendous loss for our country of a potential missed opportunity to provide paid family and medical leave. At some point, everyone will need paid leave to welcome a new child, care for a loved one, or recover from a personal illness.
